background: Super Shop sells two types of snacks in bulk and plans to create two mix products with specific percentage compositions of cat paw and gold shark snacks, aiming to maximize profit.
constraints: Amount of cat paw snacks in the first mix is non-negative
Amount of gold shark snacks in the first mix is non-negative
Amount of cat paw snacks in the second mix is non-negative
Amount of gold shark snacks in the second mix is non-negative
Total amount of cat paw snacks in both mixes cannot exceed TotalCatPaw kg
Total amount of gold shark snacks in both mixes cannot exceed TotalGoldShark kg
The first mix must contain PctCatPawFirst% cat paw snacks and PctGoldSharkFirst% gold shark snacks
The second mix must contain PctCatPawSecond% cat paw snacks and PctGoldSharkSecond% gold shark snacks
objective: Maximize the total profit from both snack mixes
description: Super Shop sells cat paw snacks and gold shark snacks in bulk. It plans to sell them into two snack mix products. The first mix contains \param{PctCatPawFirst}% cat paw snacks and \param{PctGoldSharkFirst}% gold shark snacks. The second mix contains \param{PctCatPawSecond}% cat paw snacks and \param{PctGoldSharkSecond}% gold shark snacks. The store has on hand \param{TotalCatPaw} kg of cat paw snacks and \param{TotalGoldShark} kg of gold shark snacks. If the profit per kg of the first mix is $\param{ProfitFirstMix} and the profit per kg of the second mix is $\param{ProfitSecondMix}, how many kg of each should be prepared to maximize profit?

parameters.definition: Percentage of cat paw snacks in the first snack mix
Percentage of gold shark snacks in the first snack mix
Percentage of cat paw snacks in the second snack mix
Percentage of gold shark snacks in the second snack mix
Total kg of cat paw snacks available
Total kg of gold shark snacks available
Profit per kg of the first snack mix
Profit per kg of the second snack mix
